<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Saint Peter</h1>
<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-fr-revisiontag" class="flaggedrevs_short flaggedrevs_stable_synced plainlinks noprint"><div class="flaggedrevs_short_basic"><span aria-disabled='false' title='Changes must be reviewed before being displayed on this page.' class='flaggedrevs-icon oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-articleSearch oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-labelElement-invisible oo-ui-iconWidget'></span><span id='mw-fr-revisiontoggle' aria-disabled='false' title='show/hide details' class='fr-toggle-arrow oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicator-down oo-ui-indicatorElement oo-ui-labelElement-invisible oo-ui-indicatorWidget'></span></div>
<div id="mw-fr-revisiondetails-wrapper" style="position:relative;"><div id="mw-fr-revisiondetails" class="flaggedrevs_short_details" style="display:none">This is the <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Pending_changes" title="Wikipedia:Pending changes">latest accepted revision</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Log&amp;type=review&amp;page=Saint_Peter">reviewed</a> on <i>7 September 2019</i>.</div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Saint Peter (disambiguation)">Saint Peter (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="n" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color:plum;"><div class="honorific-prefix" style="font-size: 77%; font-weight: normal;display:inline;"><a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">Saint</a></div><br /><div style="display:inline" class="fn">Apostle Peter</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="role" style="text-align:center"><i><a href="/wiki/Apostle" title="Apostle">Apostle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patriarch" title="Patriarch">Patriarch</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Martyr" title="Martyr">Martyr</a></i></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Saint Peter A33446.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg/220px-Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="359" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg/330px-Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg/440px-Saint_Peter_A33446.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2453" data-file-height="4000" /></a><div><span style="font-size:85%;"><i>Saint Peter</i> (c. 1468) by <a href="/wiki/Marco_Zoppo" title="Marco Zoppo">Marco Zoppo</a> depicts Peter as a man holding the <a href="/wiki/Keys_of_Heaven" title="Keys of Heaven">Keys of Heaven</a> and a book representing the <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">gospel</a>.</span></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Church</th><td class="org"><a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">Early Christian</a> <a href="/wiki/Great_Church" title="Great Church">Great Church</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">See</th><td>
<ul><li>First <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Bishop of Rome</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">pope</a>), according to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">Catholic</a> <a href="/wiki/Sacred_tradition" title="Sacred tradition">tradition</a></li>
<li>First <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Antioch" title="Patriarch of Antioch">Bishop of Antioch</a> (<a href="/wiki/Patriarch" title="Patriarch">patriarch</a>), according to <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christian</a> tradition</li></ul>
</td></tr><tr class="note"><th scope="row">Installed</th><td>AD 30<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr class="note"><th scope="row">Term ended</th><td>between AD 64 and 68<sup id="cite_ref-newadvent.org_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newadvent.org-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Successor</th><td>
<ul><li>Bishop of <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Rome</a>: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Linus" title="Pope Linus">Linus</a></li>
<li>Bishop of <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Antioch" title="Church of Antioch">Antioch</a>: <a href="/wiki/Evodius" title="Evodius">Evodius</a></li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#DDDDDD;">Orders</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Ordination</th><td>AD 33<br />by&#160;<a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus Christ</a></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#DDDDDD;">Personal details</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Birth name</th><td class="nickname">Shimon (Simeon, Simon)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Born</th><td><abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;AD 1</span><br /><a href="/wiki/Bethsaida" title="Bethsaida">Bethsaida</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gaulanitis" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaulanitis">Gaulanitis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria_(Roman_province)" class="mw-redirect" title="Syria (Roman province)">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Died</th><td>between AD 64 and 68 (aged 62â€“67)<br /><a href="/wiki/Clementine_Chapel" title="Clementine Chapel">Clementine Chapel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vatican_Hill" title="Vatican Hill">Vatican Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy_(Roman_Empire)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italy (Roman Empire)">Italia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Parents</th><td>John (or Jonah; Jona)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Occupation</th><td><a href="/wiki/Fisherman" title="Fisherman">Fisherman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clergy" title="Clergy">clergyman</a></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#DDDDDD;">Sainthood</th></tr><tr><th scope="row">Feast day</th><td>
<ul><li>Main feast (with <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul the Apostle</a>) 29 June (<a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" class="mw-redirect" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodoxy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutheranism</a>)<br /></li>
<li>Chair of Saint Peter in Rome 18 January (pre-<a href="/wiki/General_Roman_Calendar_of_1960" title="General Roman Calendar of 1960">General Roman Calendar of 1960</a>)</li>
<li>Confession of Saint Peter 18 January (Anglicanism)<br />Chair of Saint Peter 22 February (Catholic Church)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/San_Pietro_in_Vincoli" title="San Pietro in Vincoli">Saint Peter in Chains</a> 1 August (pre-1960 Roman Calendar)</li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Venerated in</th><td>All <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denominations</a> that venerate <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">saints</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Canonized</th><td>Pre-<a href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Causes_of_Saints" title="Congregation for the Causes of Saints">Congregation</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Attributes</th><td><a href="/wiki/Keys_of_Heaven" title="Keys of Heaven">Keys of Heaven</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_martyrs#Degrees_of_martyrdom" title="Christian martyrs">Red Martyr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pallium" title="Pallium">pallium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papal_regalia_and_insignia" title="Papal regalia and insignia">papal vestments</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rooster" title="Rooster">rooster</a>, man crucified upside down, vested as an Apostle, holding a book or scroll, <a href="/wiki/Cross_of_Saint_Peter" title="Cross of Saint Peter">Cross of Saint Peter</a>. <a href="/wiki/Iconography" title="Iconography">Iconographically</a>, he is depicted with a bushy white beard and white hair.</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Patronage</th><td><a href="#Patronage">Patronage list</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Shrines</th><td><a href="/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica" title="St. Peter&#39;s Basilica">St. Peter's Basilica</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Saint Peter</b> (<a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a>: Ü«Ü¸Ü¡Ü¥Ü˜Ü¿Ü¢ ÜŸÜ¹ÝÜÜ¦Ý‚ÜµÜ, <i>Å emÊ¿Ån KÄ“pÌ„Ä</i>; <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <span lang="he" dir="rtl">×©×ž×¢×•×Ÿ ×‘×¨ ×™×•× ×”</span>&#8206; <i lang="arc-Latn" title="Aramaic-language romanization"><i>Å imÊ¿Ån bar YÅnÄh</i></i>; <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek language text">Î Î­Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‚</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">translit.</a></small>&#160;<i lang="grc-Latn" title="Ancient Greek-language romanization"><i>Petros</i></i>; <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Coptic</a>: <span lang="cop">â²¡â²‰â²§â²£â²Ÿâ²¥</span>, <small>romanized:&#160;</small><i lang="cop-Latn" title="Coptic-language romanization">Petros</i>; <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">Petrus</i>; r. AD 30;<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> died between AD 64 and 68),<sup id="cite_ref-newadvent.org_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newadvent.org-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> also known as <b>Simon Peter</b>, <b>Simeon</b>, <b>Simon</b> (<span class="nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ëˆ/: primary stress follows">Ëˆ</span><span title="&#39;s&#39; in &#39;sigh&#39;">s</span><span title="/aÉª/: &#39;i&#39; in &#39;tide&#39;">aÉª</span><span title="&#39;m&#39; in &#39;my&#39;">m</span><span title="/É™/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">É™</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>, <span style="font-size:85%;"><span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pope_Peter_Pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/92/Pope_Peter_Pronunciation.ogg" class="internal" title="Pope Peter Pronunciation.ogg">pronunciation</a></span>&#160;<small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>Â·<a href="/wiki/File:Pope_Peter_Pronunciation.ogg" title="File:Pope Peter Pronunciation.ogg"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span></span>), <b>Sham'un al-Safa</b>, <b>Cephas</b>, or <b>Peter the Apostle</b>, was one of the <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Twelve Apostles">Twelve Apostles</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus Christ</a>, and the first leader of the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Christian#Jerusalem_ekklÄ“sia" title="Jewish Christian">early Church</a>.
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic Age">Christian tradition</a>, Peter was crucified in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> under Emperor <a href="/wiki/Nero" title="Nero">Nero</a>. He is traditionally counted as the first Bishop of Rome&#8205;&#8212;&#8204;or <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">pope</a>&#8205;&#8212;&#8204;and also by <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christian tradition</a> as the first <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Antioch" title="Patriarch of Antioch">Patriarch of Antioch</a>. The ancient Christian churches all <a href="/wiki/Veneration" title="Veneration">venerate</a> Peter as a major <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">saint</a> and as the founder of the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Antioch" title="Church of Antioch">Church of Antioch</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Roman Church</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-newadvent.org_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newadvent.org-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> but differ in their attitudes regarding the authority of his present-day successors (the <a href="/wiki/Primacy_of_the_Bishop_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Primacy of the Bishop of Rome">primacy of the Bishop of Rome</a>). According to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">Catholic teaching</a>, in <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Matthew+16:18â€“16:18&amp;version=nrsv">Matthew 16:18</a> Jesus promised Peter a <a href="/wiki/Primacy_of_Peter" title="Primacy of Peter">special position</a> in the Church.
</p><p>Two <a href="/wiki/General_epistles" class="mw-redirect" title="General epistles">general epistles</a> in the New Testament are ascribed to Peter, but modern scholars generally reject the <a href="/wiki/Authorship_of_the_Petrine_epistles" title="Authorship of the Petrine epistles">Petrine authorship</a> of both.<sup id="cite_ref-Martin_2009_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_2009-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark" title="Gospel of Mark">Gospel of Mark</a> was traditionally thought to show the influence of Peter's preaching and eyewitness memories. Several other books bearing his name&#8205;&#8212;&#8204;the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Peter" title="Acts of Peter">Acts of Peter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Peter" title="Gospel of Peter">Gospel of Peter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clementine_literature" title="Clementine literature">Preaching of Peter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apocalypse_of_Peter" title="Apocalypse of Peter">Apocalypse of Peter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judgment_of_Peter" class="mw-redirect" title="Judgment of Peter">Judgment of Peter</a>&#8205;&#8212;&#8204;are considered by Christian denominations as <a href="/wiki/New_Testament_apocrypha" title="New Testament apocrypha">apocryphal</a>, and are thus not included in their <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> canons.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Names_and_etymologies">Names and etymologies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Names and etymologies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_(1571-1610).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_%281571-1610%29.jpg/220px-The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_%281571-1610%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_%281571-1610%29.jpg/330px-The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_%281571-1610%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_%281571-1610%29.jpg/440px-The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_%281571-1610%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1202" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Calling_of_Saints_Peter_and_Andrew_-_Caravaggio_(1571-1610).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Calling of Peter and Andrew</i>, 1603/1606, <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">Caravaggio</a></div></div></div>
<p>Peter's original name, as indicated in the New Testament, was "Simon" (<span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek language text">Î£Î¯Î¼Ï‰Î½</span> <i>SimÅn</i> in <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>) or (only in <a href="/wiki/Acts_15" title="Acts 15">Acts 15</a>:14 and <a href="/wiki/2_Peter_1:1" class="mw-redirect" title="2 Peter 1:1">2 Peter 1:1</a>) "Simeon" (<span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek language text">Î£Ï…Î¼ÎµÏŽÎ½</span> in Greek). The Simon/Simeon variation has been explained as reflecting "the well-known custom among Jews at the time of giving the name of a famous patriarch or personage of the <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a> to a male child along with a similar sounding Greek/Roman name".<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>He was later given the name ×›ÖµÖ¼×™×¤Ö¸× (<i>Kepha</i>) in <a href="/wiki/Aramaic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Aramaic language">Aramaic</a>, which was rendered in Greek (by transliteration and the addition of a final <a href="/wiki/Sigma" title="Sigma">sigma</a> to make it a masculine word) as <span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek language text">ÎšÎ·Ï†á¾¶Ï‚</span> , whence <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> <i>Cephas</i> (9 occurrences in the New Testament);<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> or (by translation with masculine termination) as Î Î­Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‚, whence Latin <i>Petrus</i> and English <i>Peter</i> (156 occurrences in the New Testament).<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The precise meaning of the Aramaic word is disputed, some saying that its usual meaning is "rock" or "crag", others saying that it means rather "stone" and, particularly in its application by Jesus to Simon, "precious stone" or "jewel", but most scholars agree that as a proper name it denotes a rough or tough character.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Both meanings, "stone" (jewel or hewn stone) and "rock", are indicated in dictionaries of Aramaic<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Catholic theologian Rudolf Pesch argues that the Aramaic <i>cepha</i> means "stone, ball, clump, clew" and that "rock" is only a connotation; that in the Attic Greek <i>petra</i> denotes "grown rock, rocky range, cliff, grotto"; and that <i>petros</i> means "small stone, firestone, sling stone, moving boulder".<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The combined name <span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek language text">Î£Î¯Î¼Ï‰Î½ Î Î­Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‚</span> (Simon Peter) appears 19 times in the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>. In some <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a> documents he is called, in English translation, Simon Cephas.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biographical_information">Biographical information</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Biographical information">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ancient_capernum_is.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ancient_capernum_is.JPG/220px-Ancient_capernum_is.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ancient_capernum_is.JPG/330px-Ancient_capernum_is.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ancient_capernum_is.JPG/440px-Ancient_capernum_is.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="2136" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ancient_capernum_is.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ruins of ancient <a href="/wiki/Capernaum" title="Capernaum">Capernaum</a> on north side of the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources">Sources</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Sources">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Peter's life story is told in the four <a href="/wiki/Canonical_gospels" class="mw-redirect" title="Canonical gospels">canonical gospels</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, New Testament letters, the non-canonical <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_the_Hebrews" title="Gospel of the Hebrews">Gospel of the Hebrews</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Early_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Church">Early Church</a> accounts of his life and death. In the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, he is among the first of the disciples called during Jesus' ministry. Peter became the first listed apostle ordained by Jesus in the early church.<sup id="cite_ref-ODCC_Peter_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODCC_Peter-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accounts">Accounts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Accounts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Peter was a fisherman in <a href="/wiki/Bethsaida" title="Bethsaida">Bethsaida</a> (<a href="/wiki/John_1" title="John 1">John 1</a>:44). He was named Simon, son of Jonah or John.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> The three <a href="/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels" title="Synoptic Gospels">Synoptic Gospels</a> recount how Peter's mother-in-law <a href="/wiki/Healing_the_mother_of_Peter%27s_wife" title="Healing the mother of Peter&#39;s wife">was healed by Jesus</a> at their home in <a href="/wiki/Capernaum" title="Capernaum">Capernaum</a> (<a href="/wiki/Matthew_8" title="Matthew 8">Matthew 8</a>:14â€“17, <a href="/wiki/Mark_1" title="Mark 1">Mark 1</a>:29â€“31, <a href="/wiki/Luke_4" title="Luke 4">Luke 4</a>:38); this passage clearly depicts Peter as being married. <a href="/wiki/1_Corinthians_9" title="1 Corinthians 9">1 Corinthians 9</a>:5 has also been taken to imply that he was married.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg/240px-Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg/360px-Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg/480px-Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2730" data-file-height="2561" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Duccio_di_Buoninsegna_036.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Calling of the Apostles Peter and Andrew</i> (from the <i>MaestÃ </i>), c. 1308â€“1311</div></div></div>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels" title="Synoptic Gospels">Synoptic Gospels</a>, Peter (then Simon) was a fisherman along with his brother, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Andrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Andrew">Andrew</a>, and the sons of Zebedee, James and John. The <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a> also depicts Peter fishing, even after the resurrection of Jesus, in the story of the <a href="/wiki/Miraculous_Draught_of_Fish" class="mw-redirect" title="Miraculous Draught of Fish">Catch of 153 fish</a>. In Matthew and Mark, Jesus called Simon and his brother Andrew to be "<a href="/wiki/Fishers_of_men" title="Fishers of men">fishers of men</a>" (<a href="/wiki/Matthew_4" title="Matthew 4">Matthew 4</a>:18â€“19, <a href="/wiki/Mark_1" title="Mark 1">Mark 1</a>:16â€“17).
</p><p>A Franciscan church is built upon the traditional site of Apostle Peter's house.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
In <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Luke</a>, Simon Peter owns the boat that Jesus uses to preach to the multitudes who were pressing on him at the shore of <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Lake Gennesaret</a> (<a href="/wiki/Luke_5" title="Luke 5">Luke 5</a>:3). Jesus then amazes Simon and his companions James and John (Andrew is not mentioned) by telling them to lower their nets, whereupon they catch a huge number of fish. Immediately after this, they follow him (<a href="/wiki/Luke_5" title="Luke 5">Luke 5</a>:4â€“11). The <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a> gives a comparable account of "The First Disciples" (<a href="/wiki/John_1" title="John 1">John 1</a>:35â€“42). In John, the readers are told that it was two disciples of <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a> (Andrew and an unnamed disciple) who heard John the Baptist announce Jesus as the "<a href="/wiki/Lamb_of_God" title="Lamb of God">Lamb of God</a>" and then followed Jesus. Andrew then went to his brother Simon, saying, "We have found the <a href="/wiki/Messiah" title="Messiah">Messiah</a>", and then brought Simon to Jesus.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg/220px-Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="313" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg/330px-Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg/440px-Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg 2x" data-file-width="850" data-file-height="1211" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cavalier_d%27Arpino_-_Christ_Taken_Prisoner_-_WGA04690.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Apostle Peter striking the <a href="/wiki/High_Priest" class="mw-redirect" title="High Priest">High Priests</a>' servant <a href="/wiki/Malchus" title="Malchus">Malchus</a> with a sword in the <a href="/wiki/Garden_of_Gethsemane" class="mw-redirect" title="Garden of Gethsemane">Garden of Gethsemane</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Cesari" title="Giuseppe Cesari">Giuseppe Cesari</a> c. 1597</div></div></div>
<p>Three of the four gospels â€“ Matthew, Mark and John â€“ recount the story of Jesus <a href="/wiki/Jesus_walking_on_water" title="Jesus walking on water">walking on water</a>. Matthew additionally describes Peter walking on water for a moment but beginning to sink when his faith wavers (<a href="/wiki/Matthew_14" title="Matthew 14">Matthew 14</a>:28â€“31).
</p><p>At the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a>, Jesus washed his disciples' feet. Peter initially refused to let Jesus wash his feet, but when Jesus threatened him with: "If I wash thee not, thou hast no part with me", Peter replied: "Lord, not my feet only, but also my hands and my head" (<a href="/wiki/John_13" title="John 13">John 13</a>:2â€“11). The <a href="/wiki/Foot_washing" title="Foot washing">washing of feet</a> is often repeated in the <a href="/wiki/Service_of_worship" class="mw-redirect" title="Service of worship">service of worship</a> on <a href="/wiki/Maundy_Thursday" title="Maundy Thursday">Maundy Thursday</a> by some <a href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian denominations">Christian denominations</a>.
</p><p>The three <a href="/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels" title="Synoptic Gospels">Synoptic Gospels</a> all mention that, when Jesus was arrested, one of his companions cut off the ear of a servant of the <a href="/wiki/High_Priest_of_Israel" title="High Priest of Israel">High Priest of Israel</a> (<a href="/wiki/Matthew_26" title="Matthew 26">Matthew 26</a>:51, <a href="/wiki/Mark_14" title="Mark 14">Mark 14</a>:47, <a href="/wiki/Luke_22" title="Luke 22">Luke 22</a>:50). The Gospel of John also includes this event and names Peter as the swordsman and <a href="/wiki/Malchus" title="Malchus">Malchus</a> as the victim (<a href="/wiki/John_18" title="John 18">John 18</a>:10). Luke adds that Jesus touched the ear and miraculously healed it (<a href="/wiki/Luke_22" title="Luke 22">Luke 22</a>:49â€“51). This healing of the servant's ear is the last of the <a href="/wiki/Miracles_of_Jesus" title="Miracles of Jesus">37 miracles attributed to Jesus</a> in the Bible.
</p><p>Simon Peter was twice arraigned, with John, before the <a href="/wiki/Sanhedrin" title="Sanhedrin">Sanhedrin</a> and directly defied them (<a href="/wiki/Acts_4" title="Acts 4">Acts 4</a>:7â€“22, <a href="/wiki/Acts_5" title="Acts 5">Acts 5</a>:18â€“42). After receiving a vision from <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">God</a> that allowed for the eating of previously unclean animals, Peter takes a missionary journey to <a href="/wiki/Lod" title="Lod">Lydda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaffa,_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Jaffa, Israel">Joppa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caesarea_Maritima" title="Caesarea Maritima">Caesarea</a> (<a href="/wiki/Acts_9" title="Acts 9">Acts 9</a>:32â€“<a href="/wiki/Acts_10" title="Acts 10">Acts 10</a>:2), becoming instrumental in the decision to evangelise the <a href="/wiki/Gentile" title="Gentile">Gentiles</a> (<a href="/wiki/Acts_10" title="Acts 10">Acts 10</a>). Simon Peter applied the message of the vision on clean animals to the gentiles and follows his meeting with <a href="/wiki/Cornelius_the_Centurion" title="Cornelius the Centurion">Cornelius the Centurion</a> by claiming that 'God shows no partiality (<a href="/wiki/Acts_10" title="Acts 10">Acts 10</a>).'<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, Peter and John were sent from Jerusalem to <a href="/wiki/Samaria" title="Samaria">Samaria</a> (<a href="/wiki/Acts_8" title="Acts 8">Acts 8</a>:14). Peter/Cephas is mentioned briefly in the opening chapter of one of the <a href="/wiki/Pauline_epistles" title="Pauline epistles">Pauline epistles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Galatians" title="Epistle to the Galatians">Epistle to the Galatians</a>, which mentions a trip by <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul the Apostle</a> to <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> where he meets Peter (<a href="/wiki/Galatians_1" title="Galatians 1">Galatians 1</a>:18). Peter features again in Galatians, fourteen years later, when Paul (now with <a href="/wiki/Barnabas" title="Barnabas">Barnabas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Titus" title="Saint Titus">Titus</a>) returned to Jerusalem (<a href="/wiki/Galatians_2" title="Galatians 2">Galatians 2</a>:7-9). When Peter came to <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a>, Paul opposed Peter to his face "because he [Peter] was in the wrong" (<a href="/wiki/Galatians_2" title="Galatians 2">Galatians 2</a>:11.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Acts_12" title="Acts 12">Acts 12</a> narrates how Peter, who was in Jerusalem, was put into prison by <a href="/wiki/Agrippa_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Agrippa I">Agrippa I</a> (A.D. 42â€“44), but was <a href="/wiki/Liberation_of_Saint_Peter" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberation of Saint Peter">rescued by an angel</a>. After his liberation Peter left Jerusalem to go to "another place" (Acts 12:1â€“18). Concerning Peter's subsequent activity there is no further connected information from the extant sources, although there are short notices of certain individual episodes of his later life.<sup id="cite_ref-newadvent.org_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newadvent.org-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="First_leader_of_the_early_Church">First leader of the early Church</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: First leader of the early Church">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Christian" title="Jewish Christian">Jewish Christian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">Early Christianity</a></div>
<p>The Gospels and Acts portray Peter as the most prominent apostle, though he denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion. According to the Christian tradition, Peter was the first to whom Jesus appeared, balancing Peter's denial and restoring his position. Peter is regarded as the first leader of the early Church,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200545_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200545-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> though he was soon eclipsed in this leadership by James the Just, "the Brother of the Lord."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200545â€“46_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200545â€“46-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116â€“117_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116â€“117-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Because Peter was the first to whom Jesus appeared, the leadership of Peter forms the basis of the Apostolic succession and the institutional power of orthodoxy, as the heirs of Peter,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200543_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200543-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> and is described as "the rock" on which the church will be built.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200545_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200545-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Position_among_the_apostles">Position among the apostles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Position among the apostles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg/280px-JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg/420px-JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b4/JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="313" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:JanStyka-SaintPeter.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>St. Peter Preaching the Gospel in the Catacombs</i> by <a href="/wiki/Jan_Styka" title="Jan Styka">Jan Styka</a></div></div></div>
<p>Peter is always listed first among the Twelve Apostles in the gospels<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> and in the Book of Acts (Acts 1:13). He is also frequently mentioned in the gospels as forming with <a href="/wiki/James,_son_of_Zebedee" class="mw-redirect" title="James, son of Zebedee">James the Elder</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_the_Apostle" title="John the Apostle">John</a> a special group within the Twelve Apostles, present at incidents at which the others were not present, such as at the <a href="/wiki/Transfiguration_of_Jesus" title="Transfiguration of Jesus">Transfiguration of Jesus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> at the <a href="/wiki/Raising_of_Jairus%27_daughter" title="Raising of Jairus&#39; daughter">raising of Jairus' daughter</a><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> and at <a href="/wiki/Agony_in_the_Garden" title="Agony in the Garden">the agony</a> in the Garden of Gethsemane.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> Peter often confesses his faith in Jesus as the Messiah.
</p><p>Peter is often depicted in the gospels as spokesman of all the Apostles.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Vidmar" title="John Vidmar">John Vidmar</a>, a Catholic scholar, writes: "Catholic scholars agree that Peter had an authority that superseded that of the other apostles. Peter is their spokesman at several events, he conducts the election of Matthias, his opinion in the debate over converting Gentiles was crucial, etc.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The author of the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a> portrays Peter as central figure within the early Christian community.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;note 1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Denial_of_Jesus_by_Peter">Denial of Jesus by Peter</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Denial of Jesus by Peter">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg/220px-El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg/330px-El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg/440px-El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="483" data-file-height="500" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:El_Greco_-_Las_l%C3%A1grimas_de_San_Pedro.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The tears of Saint Peter</i>, by <a href="/wiki/El_Greco" title="El Greco">El Greco</a>, late 16th century</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Denial_of_Peter" title="Denial of Peter">Denial of Peter</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_(1610).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_%281610%29.jpg/220px-The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_%281610%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_%281610%29.jpg/330px-The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_%281610%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_%281610%29.jpg/440px-The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_%281610%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7344" data-file-height="5292" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Denial_of_Saint_Peter-Caravaggio_(1610).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Denial of Saint Peter</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">Caravaggio</a>, c. 1610</div></div></div>
<p>All four canonical gospels recount that, during the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a>, Jesus foretold that Peter would deny him three times before the following cockcrow ("before the cock crows twice" in Mark's account). The three Synoptics and John describe the three denials as follows:
</p>
<ol><li>A denial when a female servant of the high priest spots Simon Peter, saying that he had been with Jesus. According to Mark (but not in all manuscripts), "the rooster crowed". Only Luke and John mention a fire by which Peter was warming himself among other people: according to Luke, Peter was "sitting"; according to John, he was "standing".</li>
<li>A denial when Simon Peter had gone out to the gateway, away from the firelight, but the same servant girl (Mark) or another servant girl (Matthew) or a man (Luke and also John, for whom, though, this is the third denial) told the bystanders he was a follower of Jesus. According to John, "the rooster crowed". The Gospel of John places the second denial while Peter was still warming himself at the fire, and gives as the occasion of the third denial a claim by someone to have seen him in the garden of <a href="/wiki/Gethsemane" title="Gethsemane">Gethsemane</a> when <a href="/wiki/Arrest_of_Jesus" title="Arrest of Jesus">Jesus was arrested</a>.</li>
<li>A denial came when Peter's Galilean accent was taken as proof that he was indeed a disciple of Jesus. According to Matthew, Mark and Luke, "the rooster crowed". Matthew adds that it was his <a href="/wiki/Accent_(sociolinguistics)" title="Accent (sociolinguistics)">accent</a> that gave him away as coming from Galilee. Luke deviates slightly from this by stating that, rather than a crowd accusing Simon Peter, it was a third individual. John does not mention the Galilean accent.</li></ol>
<p>In the Gospel of Luke is a record of Christ telling Peter: "Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath desired to have you, that he may sift you as wheat: but I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not: and when thou art converted, strengthen thy brethren." In a reminiscent<sup id="cite_ref-May_Metzger_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-May_Metzger-37">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> scene in John's epilogue, Peter affirms three times that he loves Jesus.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Resurrection_appearances">Resurrection appearances</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Resurrection appearances">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Church_peters_primacy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Church_peters_primacy.jpg/220px-Church_peters_primacy.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Church_peters_primacy.jpg/330px-Church_peters_primacy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Church_peters_primacy.jpg/440px-Church_peters_primacy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="1899" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Church_peters_primacy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Church of the Primacy of St. Peter on the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a></div></div></div>
<p>Paul's <a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="First Epistle to the Corinthians">First Epistle to the Corinthians</a><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> contains a list of <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_appearances_of_Jesus" class="mw-redirect" title="Resurrection appearances of Jesus">resurrection appearances of Jesus</a>, the first of which is an appearance to Peter.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> Here, Paul apparently follows an early tradition that Peter was the first to see the risen Christ,<sup id="cite_ref-ODCC_Peter_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODCC_Peter-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> which, however, did not seem to have survived to the time when the gospels were written.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In John's gospel, Peter is the first person to enter the <a href="/wiki/Empty_tomb" title="Empty tomb">empty tomb</a>, although the women and the <a href="/wiki/Beloved_disciple" class="mw-redirect" title="Beloved disciple">beloved disciple</a> see it before him.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jn.+20%3A1%E2%80%939&amp;version=NRSV">&#91;Jn. 20:1â€“9&#93;</a></sup> In Luke's account, the women's report of the empty tomb is dismissed by the apostles, and Peter is the only one who goes to check for himself, running to the tomb. After seeing the graveclothes he goes home, apparently without informing the other disciples.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Lk.+24%3A1%E2%80%9312&amp;version=NRSV">&#91;Lk. 24:1â€“12&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/John_21" title="John 21">final chapter</a> of the Gospel of John, Peter, in one of the resurrection appearances of Jesus, <a href="/wiki/Restoration_of_Peter" title="Restoration of Peter">three times affirmed his love for Jesus</a>, balancing his threefold denial, and Jesus reconfirmed Peter's position. The Church of the Primacy of St. Peter on the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a> is seen as the traditional site where Jesus Christ appeared to his disciples after his resurrection and, according to Catholic tradition, established Peter's supreme jurisdiction over the Christian church.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leader_of_the_early_church">Leader of the early church</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Leader of the early church">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg/220px-Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="276" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg/330px-Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg/440px-Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg 2x" data-file-width="955" data-file-height="1200" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Liberation_of_Saint_Peter_by_Giovanni_Lanfranco-BMA.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Liberation of St. Peter</i> from prison by an angel, by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Lanfranco" title="Giovanni Lanfranco">Giovanni Lanfranco</a>, 1620â€“21</div></div></div>
<p>Peter was considered along with James the Just and John the Apostle as pillars of the Church.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Legitimised by Jesus' appearance, Peter assumed leadership of the group of early followers, forming the Jerusalem <i>ekklÄ“sia</i> mentioned by Paul.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200545_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200545-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> He was soon eclipsed in this leadership by James the Just, "the Brother of the Lord."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200545â€“46_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200545â€“46-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116â€“117_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116â€“117-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> According to LÃ¼demann, this was due to the discussions about the <a href="/wiki/Paul_and_Judaism" class="mw-redirect" title="Paul and Judaism">strictness of adherence</a> to the Jewish Law, when the more conservative faction of James the Just<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> took the overhand over the more liberal position of Peter, who soon lost influence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116â€“117_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELÃ¼demannÃ–zen1996116â€“117-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;note 2&#93;</a></sup> According to Dunn, this was not an "usurpation of power," but a consequence of Peter's involvement in missionary activities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBockmuehl201052_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBockmuehl201052-45">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> The early Church historian Eusebius (c. AD 325) records <a href="/wiki/Clement_of_Alexandria" title="Clement of Alexandria">Clement of Alexandria</a> (c. AD 190) as saying,
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>For they say that Peter and <a href="/wiki/James,_son_of_Zebedee" class="mw-redirect" title="James, son of Zebedee">James</a> (the Greater) and <a href="/wiki/John_the_Apostle" title="John the Apostle">John</a> after the ascension of our Saviour, as if also preferred by our Lord, strove not after honor, but chose <a href="/wiki/James_the_Just" class="mw-redirect" title="James the Just">James the Just</a> bishop of Jerusalem.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p><a href="/wiki/James_D._G._Dunn" class="mw-redirect" title="James D. G. Dunn">James D. G. Dunn</a> proposes that Peter was a "bridge-man" between the opposing views of Paul and <a href="/wiki/James_the_Just" class="mw-redirect" title="James the Just">James the Just</a> [italics original]:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>For <i>Peter was probably in fact and effect the bridge-man</i> (pontifex maximus!) <i>who did more than any other to hold together the diversity of <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic Age">first-century Christianity</a>.</i> James the brother of Jesus and Paul, the two other most prominent leading figures in first-century Christianity, were too much identified with their respective "brands" of Christianity, at least in the eyes of Christians at the opposite ends of this particular spectrum."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunn2002577_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunn2002577-47">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>Paul affirms that Peter had the special charge of being apostle to the Jews, just as he, Paul, was apostle to the Gentiles. Some argue <a href="/wiki/James_the_Just" class="mw-redirect" title="James the Just">James the Just</a> was <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Patriarch_of_Jerusalem" title="Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem">bishop of Jerusalem</a> whilst Peter was <a href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishop of Rome">bishop of Rome</a> and that this position at times gave James privilege in some (but not all) situations.
</p>
<h3><span id=".22Rock.22_dialogue"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="&quot;Rock&quot;_dialogue"><span id="Rock"></span>"Rock" dialogue</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: &quot;Rock&quot; dialogue">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In a dialogue between Jesus and his disciples (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.biblica.com/bible/?osis=niv:Matthew.16:13â€“16:19">Matthew 16:13â€“19</a>), Jesus asks, "Who do people say that the <a href="/wiki/Son_of_Man" class="mw-redirect" title="Son of Man">Son of Man</a> is?" The disciples give various answers. When he asks, "Who do <i>you</i> say that I am?" Simon Peter answers, "You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God." Jesus then declares:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonah, for this was not revealed to you by flesh and blood, but by my Father in heaven. And I tell you that you are Cephas (Peter) (<i>Petros</i>), and on this rock (<i>petra</i>) I will build my church, and the gates of Hades will not overcome it. I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven; whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.
</p></blockquote>
<p>A common view of Peter is provided by Jesuit Father <a href="/wiki/Daniel_J._Harrington" title="Daniel J. Harrington">Daniel J. Harrington</a>, who suggests that Peter was an unlikely symbol of stability. While he was one of the first disciples called and was the spokesman for the group, Peter is also the exemplar of "little faith". In <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+14&amp;version=NRSV">Matthew 14</a></span>, Peter will soon have Jesus say to him, "O you of little faith, why did you doubt?", and he will eventually deny Jesus three times. Thus, in light of the Easter event, Peter became an exemplar of the forgiven sinner.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Outside the Catholic Church, opinions vary as to the interpretation of this passage with respect to what authority and responsibility, if any, Jesus was giving to Peter.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> this passage is interpreted as not implying a special prominence to the person of Peter, but to Peter's position as representative of the Apostles. The word used for "rock" (<i>petra</i>) grammatically refers to "a small detachment of the massive ledge",<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> not to a massive boulder. Thus, Orthodox <a href="/wiki/Sacred_Tradition" class="mw-redirect" title="Sacred Tradition">Sacred Tradition</a> understands Jesus' words as referring to the apostolic faith.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg/220px-San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="316" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg/330px-San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg/440px-San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6744" data-file-height="9672" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:San_Pedro_en_l%C3%A1grimas_-_Murillo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Saint Peter in Tears</i> by <a href="/wiki/Bartolom%C3%A9_Esteban_Murillo" title="BartolomÃ© Esteban Murillo">BartolomÃ© Esteban Murillo</a> (1617â€“1682)</div></div></div>
<p><i>Petros</i> had not previously been used as a name, but in the Greek-speaking world it became a popular Christian name, after the tradition of Peter's prominence in the early Christian church had been established.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Apostolic_succession">Apostolic succession</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Apostolic succession">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">Apostolic succession</a></div>
<p>The leadership of Peter forms the basis of the Apostolic succession and the institutional power of orthodoxy, as the heirs of Peter,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200543_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200543-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> and is described as "the rock" on which the church will be built.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPagels200545_21-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPagels200545-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>
Catholics refer to him as chief of the Apostles,<sup id="cite_ref-CE_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CE-51">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> as do the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" class="mw-redirect" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodox</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> In Coptic Orthodox Church liturgy, he is once referred to as "prominent" or "head" among the Apostles, a title shared with Paul in the text (<i>The Fraction of Fast and Feast of the Apostles Peter and Paul in the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria</i>). Some, including the Orthodox Churches, believe this is not the same as saying that the other Apostles were under Peter's orders.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Antioch_and_Corinth">Antioch and Corinth</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Antioch and Corinth">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antioch">Antioch</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Antioch">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Incident_at_Antioch" title="Incident at Antioch">Incident at Antioch</a></div>
<p>According to the Epistle to the Galatians (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Galatians+2:11â€“2:11&amp;version=nrsv">2:11</a>), Peter went to Antioch where Paul rebuked him for following the conservative line regarding the conversion of Gentiles, having meals separate from Gentiles.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> Subsequent tradition held that Peter had been the first <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Antioch" title="Patriarch of Antioch">Patriarch of Antioch</a>. According to the writings of Origen<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-58">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> and Eusebius in his <i>Church History (III, 36)</i> Peter would have been the founder of the Church of Antioch.<sup id="cite_ref-Eusebius_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eusebius-59">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Later accounts expand on the brief biblical mention of his visit to <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Liber_Pontificalis" title="Liber Pontificalis">Liber Pontificalis</a></i> (9th century) mentions Peter as having served as bishop of Antioch for seven years, and having potentially left his family in the Greek city before his journey to Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> Claims of direct blood lineage from Simon Peter among the old population of Antioch existed in the 1st century and continue to exist today, notably by certain <a href="/wiki/Semaan" title="Semaan">Semaan</a> families of modern-day Syria and Lebanon. Historians have furnished other evidence of Peter's sojourn in Antioch.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Clementine_literature" title="Clementine literature">Clementine literature</a></i>, a group of related works written in the fourth century but believed to contain materials from earlier centuries, relate information about Peter that may come from earlier traditions. One is that Peter had a group of 12 to 16 followers, whom the Clementine writings name.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> Another is that it provides an itinerary of Peter's route from <a href="/wiki/Caesarea_Maritima" title="Caesarea Maritima">Caesarea Maritima</a> to Antioch, where he debated his adversary <a href="/wiki/Simon_Magus" title="Simon Magus">Simon Magus</a>; during this journey he ordained <a href="/wiki/Zacchaeus" title="Zacchaeus">Zacchaeus</a> as the first bishop of Caesarea and Maro as the first bishop of <a href="/wiki/Tripoli,_Lebanon" title="Tripoli, Lebanon">Tripolis</a>. Fred Lapham suggests the route recorded in the Clementine writings may have been taken from an earlier document mentioned by <a href="/wiki/Epiphanius_of_Salamis" title="Epiphanius of Salamis">Epiphanius of Salamis</a> in his <i><a href="/wiki/Panarion" title="Panarion">Panarion</a></i> called "The Itinerary of Peter".<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corinth">Corinth</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Corinth">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Peter may have visited <a href="/wiki/Corinth,_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Corinth, Greece">Corinth</a>, and maybe there existed a party of "Cephas".<sup id="cite_ref-ODCC_Peter_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODCC_Peter-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/First_Corinthians" class="mw-redirect" title="First Corinthians">First Corinthians</a> suggests that perhaps Peter visited the city of Corinth, located at Greece, during their missions.<sup class="nourlexpansion reference"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1Cor.+1%3A12&amp;version=NRSV">&#91;1Cor. 1:12&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Dionysius,_bishop_of_Corinth" class="mw-redirect" title="Dionysius, bishop of Corinth">Dionysius, bishop of Corinth</a>, in his Epistle to the Roman Church under <a href="/wiki/Pope_Soter" title="Pope Soter">Pope Soter</a> (A.D. 165â€“174) declares that Peter and Paul founded the Church of Rome and the Church of Corinth, and they have lived in Corinth for some time, and finally in Italy where they found death:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>You have thus by such an admonition bound together the planting of Peter and of Paul at Rome and Corinth. For both of them planted and likewise taught us in our Corinth. And they taught together in like manner in Italy, and suffered martyrdom at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Connection_to_Rome">Connection to Rome</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Connection to Rome">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul,_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul%2C_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg/220px-Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul%2C_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="308" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul%2C_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg/330px-Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul%2C_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul%2C_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg/440px-Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul%2C_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg 2x" data-file-width="571" data-file-height="800" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Correggio_-_The_Apostles_Peter_and_Paul,_detail_of_cupola_fresco_-_WGA05317.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Apostles Peter and Paul, detail of cupola fresco by <a href="/wiki/Correggio" class="mw-redirect" title="Correggio">Correggio</a> (1520â€“1524)</div></div></div>
<p>In a strong tradition of the <a href="/wiki/Early_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Church">Early Church</a>, Peter is said to have founded the Church in Rome with Paul, served as its bishop, authored two epistles, and then met martyrdom there along with Paul.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Papacy">Papacy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Papacy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_as_Pope.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Peter_as_Pope.png/180px-Peter_as_Pope.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="261" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Peter_as_Pope.png/270px-Peter_as_Pope.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/Peter_as_Pope.png 2x" data-file-width="281" data-file-height="407" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_as_Pope.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Saint Peter portrayed as a Pope in the <i><a href="/wiki/Nuremberg_Chronicle" title="Nuremberg Chronicle">Nuremberg Chronicle</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church speaks of the pope, the bishop of Rome, as the successor of Saint Peter. This is often interpreted to imply that Peter was the first Bishop of Rome. However, it is also said that the institution of the papacy is not dependent on the idea that Peter was Bishop of Rome or even on his ever having been in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_I" title="Pope Clement I">St. Clement</a> of Rome identifies Peter and Paul as the outstanding heroes of the faith.<sup id="cite_ref-ODCC_Peter_15-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODCC_Peter-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coming_to_Rome">Coming to Rome</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Coming to Rome">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Testament_accounts">New Testament accounts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: New Testament accounts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>There is no obvious biblical evidence that Peter was ever in Rome, but the first epistle of Peter does mention that "The church that is at Babylon, elected together with you, saluteth you; and so doth Marcus my son" (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://bible.oremus.org/?passage=1+Peter+5:13â€“5:13&amp;version=nrsv">1 Peter 5:13</a>). It is not certain whether this refers to the actual Babylon or to Rome, for which Babylon was a common nickname at the time, or to the Jewish diaspora in general, as a recent theory has proposed.<sup id="cite_ref-Zwierlein_review_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zwierlein_review-66">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vision_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vision-67">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>While the church in Rome was already flourishing when Paul wrote his <a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Romans" title="Epistle to the Romans">Epistle to the Romans</a> about AD 57,<sup id="cite_ref-Franzen,_p.26_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Franzen,_p.26-68">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> he greets some fifty people in Rome by name,<sup id="cite_ref-bibleverse-nb&#124;&#124;Romans&#124;16_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bibleverse-nb||Romans|16-69">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> but not Peter <a href="/wiki/Incident_at_Antioch" title="Incident at Antioch">whom he knew</a>. There is also no mention of Peter in Rome later during Paul's two-year stay there in <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Acts+28â€“28&amp;version=nrsv">Acts 28</a>, about AD 60â€“62.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Church_Fathers">Church Fathers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Church Fathers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The writings of the 1st century Church Father <a href="/wiki/Ignatius_of_Antioch" title="Ignatius of Antioch">Ignatius of Antioch</a> (c. 35â€“c. 107) refer to Peter and Paul giving admonitions to the Romans, indicating Peter's presence in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Irenaeus" title="Irenaeus">Irenaeus of Lyons</a> (c.130â€“c.202) wrote in the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_2nd_century" title="Christianity in the 2nd century">2nd century</a> that Peter and Paul had been the founders of the Church in Rome and had appointed <a href="/wiki/Pope_Linus" title="Pope Linus">Linus</a> as succeeding bishop.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Clement_of_Alexandria" title="Clement of Alexandria">Clement of Alexandria</a> (c. 150â€“c. 215) states that "Peter had preached the Word publicly at Rome. <i>(A.D. 190)</i>"<sup id="cite_ref-CL_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CL-72">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Origen" title="Origen">Origen</a> (184â€“253)<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-58">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> and Eusebius,<sup id="cite_ref-Eusebius_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eusebius-59">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> "after having first founded the church at Antioch, went away to Rome preaching the Gospel, and he also, after [presiding over] the church in Antioch, presided over that of Rome until his death".<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> After presiding over the church in Antioch by a while, Peter would have been succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Evodius" title="Evodius">Evodius</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> and thereafter by <a href="/wiki/Ignatius_of_Antioch" title="Ignatius of Antioch">Ignatius</a>, who was a student of <a href="/wiki/John_the_Apostle" title="John the Apostle">John the Apostle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lactantius" title="Lactantius">Lactantius</a>, in his book called <i>Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died</i>, written around 318, noted that "And while Nero reigned, the Apostle Peter came to Rome, and, through the power of God committed unto him, wrought certain miracles, and, by turning many to the true religion, built up a faithful and stedfast temple unto the Lord."<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Simon_Magus">Simon Magus</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Simon Magus">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Eusebius" title="Eusebius">Eusebius</a> of Caesarea (260/265â€“339/340) relates that when Peter confronts Simon Magus at Judea (mentioned in Acts 8), Simon Magus flees to Rome, where the Romans got to regard him as a god. According to Eusebius, his luck did not last long, since God sent Peter to Rome, and Simon was quenched and immediately destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Jerome" title="Jerome">Jerome</a> (327â€“420) "Peter went to Rome in the second year of Claudius to overthrow Simon Magus, and held the sacerdotal chair there for twenty-five years until the last, that is the fourteenth, year of Nero."<sup id="cite_ref-Jerome1_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jerome1-78">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>An apocryphal work, the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Actus_Vercellenses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Actus Vercellenses (page does not exist)">Actus Vercellenses</a></i> (7th century), a Latin text preserved in only one manuscript copy published widely in translation under the title Acts of Peter, sets Peter's confrontation with Simon Magus in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Death_and_burial">Death and burial</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Death and burial">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Crucifixion_at_Rome">Crucifixion at Rome</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Peter&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Crucifixion at Rome">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Domine,_quo_vadis.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Domine%2C_quo_vadis.jpg/170px-Domine%2C_quo_vadis.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Domine%2C_quo_vadis.jpg/255px-Domine%2C_quo_vadis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Domine%2C_quo_vadis.jpg/340px-Domine%2C_quo_vadis.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3053" data-file-height="4226" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Domine,_quo_vadis.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Domine_quo_vadis%3F" title="Domine quo vadis?">Domine quo vadis?</a></i> (1602) by <a href="/wiki/Annibale_Carracci" title="Annibale Carracci">Annibale Carracci</a></div></div></div>
